item.title: Quick Start
item.description: Quick Start The smallest .dom example looks like this: R( H("p", "Hello World"), document.body ); It displays a paragraph, saying “Hello World” in the page, using the Declarative DOM Composition syntax. item.title: Declarative DOM
item.description: Declarative DOM Composition The .dom library comes with a built-in accelerators that makes it possible to rapidly design human-readable DOM layouts without the need of JSX, or any other Javascript preprocessor. This is achieved through Proxy methods built on top of the .H (create element) function, creating a native Javascript syntactic sugar: div( div.underline( "Welcome!" ), p( "In this example we demonstrate ", "the ", b(".dom"), " accelerators." ), p( "Create ", span.

item.title: Components
item.description: Components Components let you split the UI into independent, reusable pieces, and think about each piece in isolation. Conceptually, components are like JavaScript functions. They accept arbitrary inputs (called “props”) and return Virtual DOM elements describing what should appear on the screen. item.title: Stateful Components
item.description: Stateful Components Components can only carry properties given, but can also maintain their own state. For example, consider the case of a spinner widget, where the user has two buttons : one to increment the value and one to decrement, like so: const { div, button } = H; function Spinner(props) { return div.rowflex( button("-"), div(`${props.value}`), button("+") ); } R(H(Spinner, {value: 0}), document.body); But what should happen when the user clicks the “+” or the “-” button?

item.title: Gotchas
item.description: Gotchas Since .dom is optimized for size and not for performance nor developer friendliness, you should be aware that there are few rough edges. Component roots cannot change The component state is preserved on it’s root DOM element. On it’s own turn, this element is indexed by the component’s key. This means, that once mounted, the component won’t be able to change the type of the root element, since it will be persisted in the cache.
